children.value: Derivatives can be approximated using function values at discrete points. Taylor’s theorem tells us exactly how accurate these approximations are and reveals the fundamental trade-off between truncation error and round-off error.

children.html: f(x)f(x)f(x)

children.value: Substituting into the central difference formula:

children.html: f(x0+h)−f(x0−h)2h=12h(2hf′(x0)+h36(f′′′(ξ+)+f′′′(ξ−))+O(h5))=f′(x0)+h212(f′′′(ξ−)+f′′′(ξ+))+O(h4)\begin{split} \frac{f(x_0 + h) - f(x_0 - h)}{2h} &= \frac{1}{2h}\left( 2hf'(x_0) + \frac{h^3}{6}\left( f'''(\xi^+) + f'''(\xi^-) \right) + O(h^5)\right) \\ &= f'(x_0) + \frac{h^2}{12} \left( f'''(\xi^-) + f'''(\xi^+) \right) + O(h^4) \end{split}2hf(x0​+h)−f(x0​−h)​​=2h1​(2hf′(x0​)+6h3​(f′′′(ξ+)+f′′′(ξ−))+O(h5))=f′(x0​)+12h2​(f′′′(ξ−)+f′′′(ξ+))+O(h4)​

children.value: The central difference approximation for the second derivative:

children.html: f′′(x0)≈f(x0+h)−2f(x0)+f(x0−h)h2f''(x_0) \approx \frac{f(x_0 + h) - 2f(x_0) + f(x_0 - h)}{h^2}f′′(x0​)≈h2f(x0​+h)−2f(x0​)+f(x0​−h)​
O(h2)O(h^2)O(h2)

children.value: Adding the Taylor expansions (instead of subtracting):

children.html: f(x0+h)+f(x0−h)=2f(x0)+h2f′′(x0)+O(h4)f(x_0 + h) + f(x_0 - h) = 2f(x_0) + h^2 f''(x_0) + O(h^4)f(x0​+h)+f(x0​−h)=2f(x0​)+h2f′′(x0​)+O(h4)
f′′(x0)f''(x_0)f′′(x0​)

children.value: Using symmetric stencils improves accuracy, but there are diminishing returns due to round-off error. The optimal step size balances truncation and round-off errors.
